How do masks catch particles that are smaller than the holes?

1. Small particles are sticky because of static forces
2. Large particle go straight until they hit a mask layer
Tiny particles get knocked around by molecules until they hit a fibre
3. Fibres are given an electric charge so that they attract all particles

#MaskUp

title: Langston Hughes reads The Negro Speaks of Rivers

last_post.content:
Today was my first time hearing Langston Hughes' voice. I'm glad I had the chance to listen to him reading one of his famous poems, which is apt for the first day of Black History Month in the United States, & since he was born on this day in 1901.

"I've known rivers:
I've known rivers ancient as the world and older than the
flow of human blood in human veins."

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8cKDOGhghMU

Finally watched @cldellow's video introduction to his datasette-scraper plugin and it is a really compelling demo! https://youtu.be/zrSGnz7ErNI

The plugin turns Datasette into a full web scraping environment, with the ability to configure crawls, watch your crawl queue and extract data from crawled pages into separate SQLite tables

It's really impressive, and also provides a fascinating example of advanced Datasette UI customization by a plugin

More info on the plugin here: https://datasette.io/plugins/datasette-scraper

"Knud Rasmussen's life mission was to know the world as the Inuit did, to understand the patterns of their lives, to enter their realms of magic and shamanic power. last_post.content: sometimes I turn on this random Minnesota ski hill webcam and it is absolutely mesmerizing. Teens just blasting off jumps and rails (sometimes landing, sometimes crashing) and then everyone hits the rope tow with such aplomb. "We see lots of video from mission control during ISS operations and at the front of the room there are big screens displaying things which are important to all the controllers. One of the most prominent displays is the map which shows the location of the ISS & other spacecraft as well as a bunch of cryptic, wavy lines.

Live YouTube link below

https://youtu.be/ybx_OKnD_pM

Quantum mechanics anyone? Dozens have been disappointed by UCLA’s administration ineptly standing in the way of Dr. Mike Miller being able to offer his perennial Winter UCLA math class (Ring Theory this quarter), so a few friends and I are putting our informal math and physics group back together.

We’re mounting a study group on quantum mechanics based on Peter Woit‘s Introduction to Quantum Mechanics course from 2022. We’ll be using his textbook Quantum Theory, Groups and Representations:An Introduction (free, downloadable .pdf) and his lectures from YouTube.

Shortly, we’ll arrange a schedule and some zoom video calls to discuss the material. If you’d like to join us, send me your email or leave a comment so we can arrange meetings (likely via Zoom or similar video conferencing).

Our goal is to be informal, have some fun, but learn something along the way. The suggested mathematical background is some multi-variable calculus and linear algebra. Many of us already have some background in Lie groups, algebras, and representation theory and can hopefully provide some help for those who are interested in expanding their math and physics backgrounds.

Everyone is welcome! 

#group-theory #lie-groups #peter-woit #physics #quantum-mechanics #representation-theory

https://boffosocko.com/2023/01/26/quantum-mechanics-study-group-for-peter-woit/

In a big chunk of the call, we discuss why a full-fledged OSS app like @elk is beneficial to the @vite, @nuxt, and Vue ecosystems.

Improvements to Vite plugins, Vue libs, and Nuxt modules (even new ones created from the App needs). And huge amount of DX and UX data to further enhance them and test new ideas in the future.

Some of the most active maintainers of plugins and modules have integrated their libs themselves into the project. Diving into the code base of Elk could help you learn more about these tools and how they play together.

title: Why don't Americans use electric kettles?

last_post.content: A zillion of you recommended this video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_yMMTVVJI4c by @TechConnectify talking about boiling water with kettles and you were totally right - highly entertaining and informative! Watched the entire thing with my teenager. 🙂

GRAZE FOR MASTODON

Tried following someone on their profile only to be asked to sign in? Confusing, yeah?

The Graze for Mastodon extension by @jaredzimmerman helps negate this and allows you to interact with users, even on their own instances.

I've made a short video on how to install, setup and use this great tool.

Please #boost to help spread the knowledge and if you like the content I make, feel free to subscribe to the channel.

https://youtu.be/7rEk_iOKPNo

#MastodonTips #FediTips

PIXELFED IN MASTODON?

Given the open nature of the #ActivityPub protocol, it is possible to pull in the Instagram alternative, #Pixelfed, into your Mastodon Home Timeline.
This is great for those looking for an alternative to Instagram, but not wanting to use yet another app.

Here is another short video on how this works and how you can use it yourself!

Please #boost to help spread the knowledge and if you like the content I make, feel free to subscribe to the channel.

https://youtu.be/iPq-NqtTEqU

#MastodonTips #FediTips

Going viral in hyperbolic geometry! Each tile is traversable with probability 𝑝. How many tiles can we reach in ≥𝑛 steps? Too small 𝑝 and it dies; 𝑝 big enough, it grows exponentially. A small difference in 𝑝, big consequences!

Inspired by our YouTube stats -- after our Bad Apple https://youtu.be/P9EZy8ZzlVU and Making Of https://youtu.be/NGixk6jVVNM, visible more people are watching other videos (eg https://youtube.com/watch?v=yqUv2JO2BCs). Does this mean we hit some threshold in the hyperbolic space of YouTube users?

Self Sovereign Internet idea of Phil Windley

The Internet was born without identity and permission layer as same as persistence. So #web3 and blockchains try to solve this in their way. What could #ssi offer here?

We lift transport protocols like #didcomm to give standard messaging protocols that have security and identity based on #dids

Instead of IPs we use peer-to-peer dids for every interaction with others via encrypted messages

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FtV0PV9MF88

#Astronomy #Teaching

Susumu Hirasawa - Siren
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ikGWoVqYqRU
#thestudio

watch the full video, too. take some time out of your day (< 10 mins), put it up on a big screen, and sit still. really think about what's happening here, what it takes to make this possible, how incredible it is that our species has gotten to this point

title: John Baez and James Dolan: math conversations

last_post.content:
Two hours a week I talk to James Dolan, mainly about algebraic geometry:

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLuAO-1XXEh0ZO-XC_uUYydL-qavIY3drK

I don't expect this to turn into a paper anytime soon, though I do hope to write one of my AMS Notice column about how the moduli space of triangles is connected to the moduli space of elliptic curves... an idea he came up with, probably not completely new.

One hour a week I talk to my last remaining grad student, Christian Williams. Logic and double categories!

(5/n)

title: The Secret To Learning More Complex Chords

last_post.content:
In her latest video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S21TYlzbxYc

Aimee Nolte shows us some ways we can stack a triad on top of the dominant 7th chord

1 3 5 ♭7

She plays this chord in C so it's called C7. The 5th is so obvious and bland she often leaves it out, giving what's called a 'shell voicing'

1 3 ♭7

Then she puts a triad on top of this, giving 'upper structures' like a 9th, 11th or 13th.

This is right at my level now, so I like it. Let me say a bit about it.

(1/n)

More Chopin pianists should adopt a phrasing like this ...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V8QB2B7HcLA&t=18s
